perturbation.changed_text:
3. Standstill.   (a) Each Investor agrees that, from the date of this Agreement until the expiration of the Standstill Period (as defined below), without the prior written consent of a majority of the Board specifically expressed in a written resolution, neither it nor any of its Related Persons (as defined herein) will, and it will cause each of its Related Persons not to, directly or indirectly, alone or with others, in any manner:

(iii) acquire, offer or propose to acquire, or agree to acquire, directly or indirectly, whether by purchase, tender or exchange offer, through the acquisition of control of another person, by joining a partnership, limited partnership, syndicate or other group (including any group of persons that would be treated as a single "person" under Section 13(d) of the Exchange Act), through swap or hedging transactions or otherwise, any additional securities (including common and preferred equity interests and debt that is convertible into any equity interests) of the Company or any rights decoupled from the underlying securities of the Company, that would result, or could result, in the Investor Group owning, in the aggregate (amongst all of the Investors and any Affiliate or Associate thereof), in excess of 20% of the shares of Common Stock outstanding;
perturbation.explanation: Section 3(a)(iii) originally limited the Investor Group's acquisition of additional securities to a threshold of 10% of the outstanding Common Stock. By changing this limit to 20%, I've introduced a contradiction. The agreement is built around the premise that the Investor Group will not exceed a certain ownership threshold to maintain a balance of power and influence. Now, they can potentially acquire twice as many shares. In this modification, it creates a conflict regarding what constitutes an acceptable level of investor influence and control, because if Investor Group had 10-20% of Company's Shares, it might affect other shareholders' votes.

perturbation.changed_text: 15. Representative. Each Investor hereby irrevocably appoints Jeffrey B. Osher as its attorney-in-fact and representative (the "Investor Group Representative"), in such Investor's place and stead, to do any and all things and to execute any and all documents and give and receive any and all notices or instructions in connection with this Agreement and the transactions contemplated hereby. The Company shall be entitled to rely, as being binding on each Investor, upon any action taken by the Investor Group Representative or upon any document, notice, instruction or other writing given or executed by the Investor Group Representative. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any Investor may individually revoke the authority of the Investor Group Representative with respect to its own shares, provided that notice of such revocation is given to the Company.
perturbation.explanation: Section 15 establishes Jeffrey B. Osher as the Investor Group Representative, granting him authority to act on behalf of all investors. By adding the sentence "Notwithstanding the foregoing, any Investor may individually revoke the authority of the Investor Group Representative with respect to its own shares, provided that notice of such revocation is given to the Company," I've created a contradiction. This allows individual investors to undermine the Representative's authority, creating uncertainty about his actual power and introducing the possibility of conflicting instructions to the Company. This makes the Representative's role uncertain. Also, what would happen if other Investors did not agree with such decision? This creates a legal dispute between them.

perturbation.original_text: 23. Amendment. This Agreement may be modified, amended or otherwise changed only in a writing signed by all of the parties hereto, or in the case of the Investors, the Investor Group Representative, or their respective successors or assigns.
perturbation.changed_text: 23. Amendment. This Agreement may be modified, amended or otherwise changed only in a writing signed by all of the parties hereto. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Company may unilaterally amend Exhibit A to include additional director candidates without the consent of the Investors.
perturbation.explanation: Section 23 states that amendments require agreement from all parties. By adding "Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Company may unilaterally amend Exhibit A to include additional director candidates without the consent of the Investors," I create a contradiction. This grants the Company the power to change a key part of the agreement (the list of director candidates) without investor consent, conflicting with the initial requirement for mutual agreement. This gives the Company more power in deciding whom to elect into Board, which may not be aligned with Investors.
